content:
SMTP is an outgoing protocol and while there are some providers that use the same server name for incoming and outgoing generally they use a port to determine the protocol that answers when a request is made to the server.

Note that generally it is antivirus programs that mess up account creation. That outlook works and Thunderbird does not on the same device actually increases the chance of it being antivirus related as Outlook relies on the Windows certificate store for encryption and it is very easily manipulated programmatically to add dud certifying authorities. Thunderbird has no programmatic manipulation, instead requiring a manual adding of "new" trusted certifying authorities. So if you are using SSL/TLS or StartTLS then my guess is your antivirus is the root problem.
creator: MattAuSupport

The same page says "If you need help donating to Thunderbird and did not find an answer in our FAQs, please fill out this form" but instead of doing that you chose to use the link to Technical Support.

Your question is not technical support and is simply inappropriate for a peer support forum such as this so I am closing it. The people who answer questions here, for the most part, are other users volunteering their time (like me), not Mozilla employees. Perhaps use the link in the donor help page to complete the form and get your response from those that are employed in donor support. No one here is even competent to answer the question.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Thunderbird is just a program sending emails, it is the server that is rejecting the emails. The server is generating the error message back to Thunderbird so you can see why server is not allowing your emails.

Testing via webmail will not provide any answer because you are not sending via smtp.

I'm assuming you are using the correct smtp settings. Outgoing server SMTP details

  • Outgoing server address: smtp.telstra.com
  • IF port: 465
  • USE: Connection SEcurity: SSL/TLS
  • IF port: 587
  • USE: Connection SEcurity: STARTTLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username: Your Telstra email address - ending in ‘@bigpond.com’, ‘@bigpond.net.au’ or ‘@telstra.com.’
  • Password: Your Telstra email account password - REMEMBER it’s case sensitive.


But the issue does not state your settings are wrong. The Server spam filter has been triggered for your emails.

I've had a look on internet and discovered this is a common occurance with Telsta and can occur using any third party email client.

Rejection could be due to IP address so check the following most common reasons:

You can check to see if your IP address or email address has been blacklisted:

  • https://check.spamhaus.org/

Some people found that if they unplugged the router/hub for about 10 minutes and then switched it on again, then restarted their email client all started working again as a new IP address had been reset.

If you have recently enabled a VPN then this may trigger a Spam rejection because it is not using your IP address, so please check to see if you have a VPN enabled and switch it off. Many Anti-Virus products now offer a VPN. Maybe the Anti-Virus got updated and it auto enabled a VPN. I've come across people who discovered it had been auto enabled and it was causing a problem.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: You never shared whatever the error message was. It may be that your email provider has a limit on recipients. If you regularly send to this many recipients, I suggest investigating the use of a mailing service, such as Mailchimp or others.

content: - highlight Local Folders - rightclick and select the importexport menu option to import mbox - then, locate and select the file that does NOT have an extension (ignore the msf file) - and you're done.
